author: Hannah Withiam
title: ESPN’s shakeup continues: ‘Mike & Mike’ are splitting up
text:
ESPN’s latest attempt at a shake-up is more about a breakup.
The Worldwide Leader in Sports is expected to assign longtime radio host Mike Greenberg to a new morning television show, according to Sports Illustrated, thus removing one “Mike” from the popular ESPN Radio show “Mike & Mike” that has run for over 18 years.
Greenberg’s new show will reportedly air mornings from a New York City studio and feature elements of “SportsCenter,” ESPN’s flagship program.
The long-rumored move comes in the wake of several scheduling and personnel changes the network has introduced in an effort to spice up its content as ratings drop and competition rises. The network has moved “His & Hers” co-hosts Michael Smith and Jemele Hill to the 6 p.m. edition of “SportsCenter” effective next month, shifted Stephen A. Smith’s debate-style “First Take” to ESPN from ESPN2 and a week ago confirmed Chris Berman’s departure after 38 iconic years on “Sunday NFL Countdown” among other shows.
The decision to bring an end to ESPN Radio’s signature morning show, which has aired since 1998 with Greenberg and Golic at the helm, opens uncharted territory for both veteran ESPN employees.
According to SI, Trey Wingo, a current host of “SportsCenter” and “NFL Live,” stands as the leading candidate to replace Greenberg on “Mike & Mike” (“Mike & Trey”?). Wingo, who has previous experience on ESPN Radio, is also in the running to take over Berman’s NFL duties, too. Golic’s son, Mike Jr., is also expected to have some role in the new program. He is currently a college football analyst for the network.
The move opens a new opportunity for Greenberg, but jeopardizes a consistent program and a known revenue provider.
